author: protolambda
content: Main difference is that the rust packs the different arrays into a single array of structs. I was just messing with minimalism at the time of design (a working dag as just an array...) and split it in different arrays. Aside from localizing reads/writes, there's little benefit, and the Rust is more readable and has nice safety checks and errors.

author: protolambda
content: Edit: localizing reads/writes is also interesting, the struct may actually work better for the single-loop mixed usage the algorithm is. But not micro-benching it. Just go with readability üëç

author: terence0083
content: What's the difference between best child versus best target/descendant?

author: protolambda
content: best target is poor naming, it's more like "best head"; skipping right to the end of the tree

author: protolambda
content: I wasn't concerned as much with ffg as just pure ghost and the dag structure when naming the variables in go code

author: terence0083
content: Wouldn't they be the same? I guess I'm not understanding why there needs to be two ways to express "best child/descendent/head"

author: protolambda
content: best child is the direct node under a parent, used in some checks (this is GhoST, with GST for greedy subtree, thus immediate child weight counts, not the eventual head)

author: protolambda
content: and then the other is to just have that nice O(1) head lookup, to not walk best-childs (although cost wouldn't be high)
